. Freising is probably best known for the world's oldest brewery, a former monastery, and the fact that a big part of the world's brewers have learned their profession at the city's university.

Even though archaeological finds show that the area was settled in the Bronze Age, there is no evidence that there existed a continous settlement until the 8th century, when Saint Corbinian settled at a shrine on

hill in 724. Corbinian was the forerunner and first bishop of the diocese of Freising. Freising quickly became an important town and religious center in Bavaria, and therefore emperor Otto III granted the settlement city rights in 996. The town significance sharply declined, though, when Duke Henry the Lion destroyed Freising's Isar bridges and salt works in 1158, to boost his own Isar crossing in Munich, which by the time was a mere toll station. However, the prince-bishopric of Freising kept its independence and religious importance until the beginning of the 19th century, when it was politically seized by Bavaria and religiously merged with the diocese of Munich.

During World War II Freising was only of minor importance and moreover housed a military hospital for foreign officers, and was therefore considered safe from attacks and destruction. The only major air raid was conducted short before the end of the war on 18.04.1945 against the city's station. On 29.04.1945 Freising surrendered to the approaching American troops (after a brief artillery bombardment), but the retrackting SS managed to blow up the city's main bridge in an attempt to delay the American advance.

Freising's economical resurgence and major growth began with the planning and construction of

, which was opened in 1992 on the city's territory. Today Freising is an economic heavyweight, with one of the highest population growth rates and lowest unemployment rates in Germany. The city's university, which is part of the Technical University Munich, is renowned in the field of life science, agriculture, and brewing technology, and the research institutes in its surroundings are famous in the scientific community. The city's most famous institution, however, is '''''Weihenstephan
, which was founded in 1040 and therefore is the world's oldest brewery.
The city is easily reachable by plane via

, which in fact is located on Freising's territory. Munich Airport is the 7th busiest in Europe and has international connections to most major cities in Europe and also sees a lot of intercontinental flights.
connects the airport to the city.
Freising is part of Greater Munich's public transportation network MVV. The

leaves Munich Central Station every 20 min and needs approx. 45 min to reach Freising. Be aware that the S1 train is split before it reaches Freising and one half is going to the airport, so make sure you are in the right part.

Freising station is also a major stop on the regional train line from
. Virtually every train along that line is calling at Freising, with the major benefit of a much faster speed.
Freising is well connected to the German autobahn network. The city has three exits -
in west-eastern direction, and one exit -

Due to the relatively compact size of the city, Freising is easily navigable on foot, whereas parking is scarce and going by car therefore not a real option. For those refusing any exercise the city provides a bus system, which is also part of Munich's public transportation system MVV.

value: name=Baroque hall of the Cathedral library
content=Built in 1732, the library was planned as a representative "public" library from the start - the first and only library open to the public in Bavaria at that time.

was founded in 1040, which makes it the oldest still existing brewery in the world. Today it is owned by the state of Bavaria and affiliated to the Technical University Munich. There are two different tours available: The small tour through the plant (1 h) contrary to the big tour (2 h) does not include a beer dégustation and a free glass.
content=The museum is all about Freising's city history. The focus lies on the city here and not on the diocese.
content=One of the many sights connected to Catholicism, this museum shows catholic works of art.
content=The cathedral was the center of the diocese of Freising from its first constrcution in 860 until 1821, when the bishop moved to Munich and
became the new cathedral. The church is on top of a steep hill overlooking Freising and Upper Bavaria, with views as far as Munich and the Bavarian Alps. Especially the crypt and the
chapel are masterpeices of architecture and art. There are tours available for €4.50 (60 min).
content=The plantation is part of the Weihenstephan-Triesdorf University of Applied Science. It is open to the public to stroll through and it and enjoy the combination of different plants.
content=Uferlos is a culture and music festival with performances, a market for handicraft and art, and food stalls.
content=PLUS is a neat music festival at small lake outside Freising. The line-up is made up of mostly local and German bands.
content=Here you can buy everything for your daily needs. There is also a pharmacy and a hairdresser.
content=The Bräustüberl is next to the premises of the
brewery on top of a steep hill. The restaurants serves traditional Bavarian cuisine. They also have a beer garden, where you are allowed to bring your own food, and just have to buy the drinks.

content=Hofbräuhauskeller is part of Hofbräuhaus Freising and located right behind the Baroque Revival brewery. The restaurant serves Bavarian food and also has a beer garden, where you can bring your own food.
content=Every bigger town in Bavaria needs its own wheat beer (
) brewery and this used to be Freising's, before the brewery was baught by Hofbräuhaus Freising. The restaurant in the city center serves traditional Bavarian food and has also has a beer garden.

content=The speciatlity of this students pub is the huge selection of beers - they generally serve more than 40 different varieties of regional beers, plus changing specials. The homemade pizza goes well with the hoppy beverages.
content=The place is a Cuban themed cocktail bar at Marienplatz, the very center of the city.
content=Carlitos is a small cozy pub with fair prizes, that is always well-frequented.
content=The hotel is located in an historic town building in the center and has 70 room.
there is a free-of-charge wifi hotspot. Without prior registration everybody has 30 min free internet and data transmission.
content=Dachau is a suburb of Munich and reminder of the darkest days of German history. Prepare to be shocked by the atrocities committed by the Nazis during the Third Reich era displayed at the
content=The city is home to Europe's biggest spa.
content=The capital of Lower Bavaria is a short 20 min away by train to the east. The city's main attractions are the quadrennial
, which takes place in the well preserved medieval city center, and St. Martin's Church, the highest church in Bavaria.
content=Bavaria's state capital and its cultural and economical focal point is only a short train ride to the south.
content=A beautiful mediaeval city at the shores of the river Danube, only 60 min from Freising by train. It's historical city center is a UNESCO World Heritage Site in its entirety.
